title: What books are a good introduction for philosophy of science? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have the book that you looking for >> Philosophy of Science: A Very Short Introduction 1st Edition What is science? Is there a real difference between science and myth? Is science objective? Can science explain everything? This Very Short Introduction provides a concise overview of the main themes of contemporary philosophy of science. Beginning with a short history of science to set the scene, Samir Okasha goes on to investigate the nature of scientific reasoning, scientific explanation, revolutions in science, and theories such as realism and anti-realism. He also looks at philosophical issues in particular sciences, including the problem of classification in biology, and the nature of space and time in physics. The final chapter touches on the conflicts between science and religion, and explores whether science is ultimately a good thing. About the Series: Combining authority with wit, accessibility, and style, Very Short Introductions offer an introduction to some of life's most interesting topics. Written by experts for the newcomer, they demonstrate the finest contemporary thinking about the central problems and issues in hundreds of key topics, from philosophy to Freud, quantum theory to Islam. For Moderator this is serious answer.

You should read Karl Popper’s Logic of Scientific Discovery. Popper made significant thesis on what is science with his fasfiability and testability doctrines. The book also explores other aspects of theory building, for instance structure and definition of simplicity. From classical philosophy, you should read Hegel ‘s Phenomenology of History. It deals with epistemology of science, perhaps the best treatment in epistemology. Hegel is difficult to read and thereby less understood and sometimes rubbished (et al Schopenhauer). You may come across Bertrand Russel. However I am not a big fan of him, if I understood him well.
